reviews.review_msg: His lectures are good but the problem is that he teaches you questions that are way easier than what he expects you to solve. Intuition for solving problems is also something he didnt really give much of. Brutal final exam avg was around 40%

Hardest class I've taken so far. His slides are too cluttered, and homework was tough but doable, exams were brutal (midterm avg: 50%, final avg: 40%). He pulls questions from MIT-level sources. Also, he can be rude if you give an “interesting” answer. Even scoring above avg, I got a B-. Not a GPA booster! Curve was just 1.02x.

Sharan explains topics very well, and he tries to make the lectures engaging. He also replies really quickly to questions on piazza. But the exams were tough, especially the finals. Maybe don't make 30% of the final about a topic that we've learned 3 days ago on the last day of class. Overall, good prof but hard class

He cares for the students and listens to our feedback. He posts answers to hws and tuts. All material in lectures relate to what we need to know and he goes through many examples. This class was hw heavy but the hw was not bad. He knows what he's doing and also enjoys it. Too bad the class was at 830 and I found the material difficult.

He's literally so smart. His lectures are basically repeating the textbook but he makes it very understandable. Assignments were difficult but graded easily. Go to office hours as much as possible for assignments since they give big hints towards the answers. Test questions came from the textbook and very difficult. Do the textbook questions.

Sharan Vaswani is pretty ehhh. Assignments make up a lot of the mark and are really difficult especially if you dont have friends to chat with or use ChatGPT to get an idea of wtf to do. The lectures are meh, explanation of concepts is ok but could be much better imo. Overall kinda meh course with this prof

Chill prof who responds to messages very quickly. Slides are very neat and he shares annotated versions of them. Allows a cheat sheet for the final, which was really nice, as the exams were pretty difficult. The assignments, worth 45% total, were pretty lenient in marking, resulting in extremely averages (which were brought down by exams marks).

The lectures are pretty good and course policy in general is quite lenient (lecture/tutorial participation not mandatory, weighted passing average on exams not needed to pass the course, detailed solutions to assignments/tutorials posted consistently), but the sheer difficulty for a lower division course makes me unwilling to recommend to take

I think he's great, I like him a lot. Knowledgable and clear lecturer. The only downside is that his confidence in us is a little bit high, definitely not an easy course by any stretch of imagination and the midterm was also hard given the time constraint. Hope he makes the final a little more reasonable. But overall, not bad! Thanks prof!

Great professor, his lectures are pretty good as he provide the theory and then does some application with them, which is appreciated versus just spitting out theory like other profs. Assignments and tutorials are hard, but set you up well for tests, which are VERY HARD. But otherwise, he is a good lecturer and I'd recommend taking him for 210.
Great Prof! One of the best ones at sfu.His lectures are thorough. He focus on explaining concepts rather than providing formulas to solve problems. Exams and assignments are tough.

His lectures are some of the best, the concepts were explained clearly. But, the tests are just too difficult. Expect similar question difficulty to the assignments, i.e. don't expect questions where you only have to apply one theorem, or even know which to apply. Overall you learn a lot, because you are forced to understand everything well.

Genuinely nice guy. Very accessible through office hours and piazza. Lectures are very thorough but do little to build intuition so can be hard to follow. You'll have to do lots of self-study to fully understand concepts. Homework and exams are very difficult.

Very knowledgeable, you will learn a lot. Yet unprofessional, mean and condescending to students, meanwhile like to use gaslighting techniques to ensure itself to look innocent. Unclear and ad hoc grading criteria, and able to make very good use of its roles' administrative power to make students suffer. Recommend to avoid at all cost.

The course covers optimization in a modern ML setting, with an emphasis on proving why things happen. You'll learn a lot and get better at math, but will spend more time than expected doing it. Grading is very fair. Overall strong recommend!
Difficult, but you'll learn a lot. It's worth taking.

Course material: very good. A combination of basics and frontier research topics. You can't find a textbook to learn these by yourself.
Workload: much heavier than normal 3-credit courses. It requires extra motivation and commitment, but you did learn a lot.
Logistics: A little bit disorganized. Hope for improvements in following iterations.

The problem sets are fairly difficult but were very useful for grasping the material. There's a final group project where you improve on a recent optimization paper. Overall a lot of fun, but probably more work than three credits.

Took his class in his first teaching term and I though he did pretty good. He had a piazza and office hours where he would always answer question quickly and his website included all the lectures filled in and posted along with free textbook pdfs and the chapters + the chapters we should review. Tough tests, but good class overall, learned a lot.
